payload.title: Arriving for Pilgrimage
payload.description: Makkah has no airport; most travelers land at Jeddah (JED). The **Haramain High-Speed Railway (HHR)** is the fastest link, reaching Makkah in under an hour.
payload.criticalAlert: You **must** download the **Nusuk App** before arrival. It is required to book your Umrah slot and enter the Rawdah in Madinah. Without a digital permit, you will be denied entry to the Haram courtyards.
tips: **Haramain Train Booking:** Tickets sell out weeks in advance for Ramadan and Hajj. Book via the HHR website or app as soon as your visa is issued.
**Nusuk Card:** Upon arrival, you will receive a physical/digital Nusuk Card. Keep this on you at all times; it is your mandatory ID for all holy sites in 2026.

**Ihram Prep:** If arriving via JED airport and intending to perform Umrah immediately, it is most convenient to change into **Ihram** at the airport's dedicated Miqat zones before boarding the train or taxi.
**Free Shuttles:** Many hotels in the Aziziyah district offer free 24/7 shuttles to the Haram, but these stop running 1 hour before and after prayer times due to crowd control.

payload.title: Getting Around Makkah
payload.description: The **Makkah Bus Project** now covers the entire city with 12 main routes, significantly reducing the need for expensive taxis.
payload.criticalAlert: Avoid unlicensed private cars offering 'cheap' rides outside the Haram. Stick to official yellow taxis or ride-hailing apps like **Careem** or **Uber** to ensure tracked routes and fair pricing.
tips: **Makkah Bus App:** Use the app to top up your E-wallet. You can pay by scanning a QR code on the bus validator. Cash is generally not accepted on board.
**Peak Traffic:** During the last 10 days of Ramadan, the central area is restricted to pedestrians only. Expect to walk 15–30 minutes from your drop-off point to the Masjid al-Haram gates.
**The 'Z' Gates:** Major construction in 2026 may shift entry points. Follow the green 'Gate' signage on the Nusuk app for real-time crowd-flow directions.

payload.title: Digital Payments & SAR
payload.description: Saudi Arabia has rapidly moved toward a cashless society. Mada (local debit), Visa, and Apple Pay are accepted even in small shops.
payload.criticalAlert: While digital pay is everywhere, keep some cash (SAR 100–200) for small charity (Sadaqah) or for 'Zamzam' water vendors outside official areas who may not have card terminals.
tips: **Currency Exchange:** Avoid the small kiosks directly facing the Haram gates as they offer poor rates. Use the bank-affiliated exchange centers inside the Clock Tower (Abraj Al Bait) malls.
**ATM Safety:** Only use ATMs attached to major banks (SNB, Al Rajhi, Alinma) to avoid skimming and ensure lower transaction fees.

**Zamzam Water:** Official 5L bottles for departure can only be purchased at the airport with a valid Umrah/Hajj visa. Do not buy 'sealed' bottles from street vendors for flights; they will be confiscated.
